title: An overview of tRavis
text: Clean annotation files (CSV TSV) Pseudomonas aeruginosa https://pseudomonas.com. add extra columns fill empty names corresponding locus tag.
code: # A URL can also be supplied, instead of a local file path link <- paste0(   "https://pseudomonas.com/downloads/pseudomonas/pgd_r_22_1/",   "Pseudomonas_aeruginosa_PAO1_107/Pseudomonas_aeruginosa_PAO1_107.csv.gz" )  tr_anno_cleaner(input_file = link) #> # A tibble: 5,713 × 3 #>    locus_tag gene_name product_name                                   #>    <chr>     <chr>     <chr>                                          #>  1 PA0001    dnaA      chromosomal replication initiator protein DnaA #>  2 PA0002    dnaN      DNA polymerase III, beta chain                 #>  3 PA0003    recF      RecF protein                                   #>  4 PA0004    gyrB      DNA gyrase subunit B                           #>  5 PA0005    lptA      lysophosphatidic acid acyltransferase, LptA    #>  6 PA0006    NA        conserved hypothetical protein                 #>  7 PA0007    NA        hypothetical protein                           #>  8 PA0008    glyS      glycyl-tRNA synthetase beta chain              #>  9 PA0009    glyQ      glycyl-tRNA synthetase alpha chain             #> 10 PA0010    tag       DNA-3-methyladenine glycosidase I              #> # ℹ 5,703 more rows tr_anno_cleaner(link, extra_cols = TRUE, fill_names = TRUE) #> # A tibble: 5,713 × 6 #>    locus_tag gene_name product_name                           start   end strand #>    <chr>     <chr>     <chr>                                  <dbl> <dbl> <chr>  #>  1 PA0001    dnaA      chromosomal replication initiator pro…   483  2027 +      #>  2 PA0002    dnaN      DNA polymerase III, beta chain          2056  3159 +      #>  3 PA0003    recF      RecF protein                            3169  4278 +      #>  4 PA0004    gyrB      DNA gyrase subunit B                    4275  6695 +      #>  5 PA0005    lptA      lysophosphatidic acid acyltransferase…  7018  7791 -      #>  6 PA0006    PA0006    conserved hypothetical protein          7803  8339 -      #>  7 PA0007    PA0007    hypothetical protein                    8671 10377 +      #>  8 PA0008    glyS      glycyl-tRNA synthetase beta chain      10434 12488 -      #>  9 PA0009    glyQ      glycyl-tRNA synthetase alpha chain     12488 13435 -      #> 10 PA0010    tag       DNA-3-methyladenine glycosidase I      13540 14091 +      #> # ℹ 5,703 more rows

title: An overview of tRavis
text: Takes DESeq2 results object, returns significant DE genes, printing message summarizing comparison number significant genes inform = TRUE (default). default filters applied data : padj < 0.05 abs(log2FoldChange) > log2(1.5).

title: An overview of tRavis
text: Compare two lists find common/unique elements, optional names argument apply results.

title: An overview of tRavis
text: Create named list files, easily piped purrr::map(~read.csv(.x)) generate named list data frames. Supports recursive searching, custom string/pattern removal, date removal assuming format like YYYYMMDD (can’t contain punctuation/symbols).
code: tr_get_files(   directory = system.file("extdata", package = "tRavis"),   pattern = "test",   date = TRUE,   remove_string = "test_" ) #> $file1 #> [1] "/home/runner/work/_temp/Library/tRavis/extdata/test_file1_20191231.csv" #>  #> $file2 #> [1] "/home/runner/work/_temp/Library/tRavis/extdata/test_file2_20200101.csv"

title: An overview of tRavis
text: Generate RNA-Seq QC plots MultiQC outputs. Currently supports summary plots FastQC (Phred scores read counts), STAR, HTSeq. Plots created ggplot2 simplicity. arguments provided modify overall font size, set limits, toggle threshold line given number reads/counts:
code: multiqc_data <- system.file("extdata/tr_qc_plots_data", package = "tRavis") list.files(multiqc_data) #> [1] "fastqc_per_base_sequence_quality_plot.tsv" #> [2] "multiqc_fastqc.txt"                        #> [3] "multiqc_htseq.txt"                         #> [4] "multiqc_star.txt" qc_plot_output <- tr_qc_plots(   directory = multiqc_data,   threshold_line = 5e6,   font_size = 14 )  qc_plot_output[["plots"]] #> $phred_scores #>  #> $fastqc_reads #>  #> $star #>  #> $htseq

title: An overview of tRavis
text: bar plots work well enough relatively samples, quickly become unwieldy lots samples. Box plots can also generated using function follows:  points can toggled using add_points argument.
code: qc_plot_output_box <- tr_qc_plots(   directory = multiqc_data,   type = "box",   threshold_line = 5e6,   font_size = 16 )  qc_plot_output_box[["plots"]][c("fastqc_reads", "star", "htseq")] #> $fastqc_reads #>  #> $star #>  #> $htseq

title: An overview of tRavis
text: underlying tidy data also returned, one can easily generate plots examine data desired: Phred scores FastQC reads STAR HTSeq
code: qc_plot_output[["data"]][["phred_scores"]] #> # A tibble: 760 × 3 #>    sample    position phred_score #>    <chr>        <dbl>       <dbl> #>  1 sample_01        1        35.5 #>  2 sample_02        1        35.5 #>  3 sample_03        1        35.5 #>  4 sample_04        1        35.5 #>  5 sample_05        1        35.5 #>  6 sample_06        1        35.5 #>  7 sample_07        1        35.5 #>  8 sample_08        1        35.5 #>  9 sample_09        1        35.5 #> 10 sample_10        1        35.6 #> # ℹ 750 more rows qc_plot_output[["data"]][["fastqc_reads"]] #> # A tibble: 40 × 3 #>    sample    read_type   n_reads #>    <fct>     <chr>         <dbl> #>  1 sample_03 unique     2685620. #>  2 sample_03 duplicate 10908567. #>  3 sample_02 unique     2803309. #>  4 sample_02 duplicate 11083659. #>  5 sample_05 unique     3006011. #>  6 sample_05 duplicate 12419121. #>  7 sample_12 unique     3186383. #>  8 sample_12 duplicate 12738310. #>  9 sample_19 unique     2725919. #> 10 sample_19 duplicate 14029645. #> # ℹ 30 more rows qc_plot_output[["data"]][["star"]] #> # A tibble: 100 × 3 #>    sample    read_type   n_reads #>    <fct>     <fct>         <dbl> #>  1 sample_03 unique      6352702 #>  2 sample_03 multimapped 3876206 #>  3 sample_03 too many       2908 #>  4 sample_03 too short   3354213 #>  5 sample_03 unmapped       8158 #>  6 sample_02 unique      6489051 #>  7 sample_02 multimapped 3880477 #>  8 sample_02 too many       2416 #>  9 sample_02 too short   3509469 #> 10 sample_02 unmapped       5555 #> # ℹ 90 more rows qc_plot_output[["data"]][["htseq"]] #> # A tibble: 100 × 3 #>    sample    read_type  n_reads #>    <fct>     <fct>        <dbl> #>  1 sample_03 assigned   4724190 #>  2 sample_03 ambiguous  1228684 #>  3 sample_03 not unique 3876206 #>  4 sample_03 no feature  399828 #>  5 sample_03 low aQual        0 #>  6 sample_02 assigned   4831854 #>  7 sample_02 ambiguous  1243270 #>  8 sample_02 not unique 3880477 #>  9 sample_02 no feature  413927 #> 10 sample_02 low aQual        0 #> # ℹ 90 more rows

title: An overview of tRavis
text: Sort column alphanumeric strings (non-binary) numerical order given input data frame desired column. can use column name index, compatible pipes.
code: df_unsorted <- data.frame(   colA = c("a11", "a1", "b1", "a2"),   colB = c(3, 1, 4, 2) )  tr_sort_alphanum(input_df = df_unsorted, sort_col = "colA") #>   colA colB #> 2   a1    1 #> 4   a2    2 #> 1  a11    3 #> 3   b1    4

title: An overview of tRavis
text: Simple wrapper around Fisher’s test gene enrichment, constructs matrix returns p value.
code: all_genes <- paste0("gene", sample(1:10000, 5000)) de_genes <- sample(all_genes, 1500) gene_set <- sample(all_genes, 100)  tr_test_enrichment(   query_set = de_genes,    enrichment_set = gene_set,    total_genes = 5000 ) #> [1] 0.05127792

title: An overview of tRavis
text: Clean themes ggplot2 improve default increasing font size, changing background white, adding border. default uses minimal grid, can easily remove grid entirely.
code: library(ggplot2) basic_box_plot <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(as.factor(cyl), mpg)) + geom_boxplot()  basic_box_plot + tr_theme() basic_box_plot + tr_theme(grid = FALSE)

title: An overview of tRavis
text: Combines items “greater” “less” list output gage single tidy data frame (tibble), provides option filter results based q value.
code: tibble_head <- function(x) {   head(dplyr::as_tibble(x, rownames = "rownames")) }  gage_untidy <-    readRDS(system.file("extdata", "ex_gage_results.rds", package = "tRavis"))  # Have a look at the original results lapply(gage_untidy, tibble_head) #> $greater #> # A tibble: 6 × 7 #>   rownames                      p.geomean stat.mean  p.val q.val set.size   exp1 #>   <chr>                             <dbl>     <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl>    <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1 pae00470 D-Amino acid metabo…    0.0630     1.61  0.0630 0.924       10 0.0630 #> 2 pae01232 Nucleotide metaboli…    0.111      1.24  0.111  0.924       16 0.111  #> 3 pae00640 Propanoate metaboli…    0.167      0.994 0.167  0.924       11 0.167  #> 4 pae00330 Arginine and prolin…    0.179      0.937 0.179  0.924       14 0.179  #> 5 pae03010 Ribosome                0.197      0.862 0.197  0.924       19 0.197  #> 6 pae01210 2-Oxocarboxylic aci…    0.250      0.684 0.250  0.924       12 0.250  #>  #> $less #> # A tibble: 6 × 7 #>   rownames                      p.geomean stat.mean  p.val q.val set.size   exp1 #>   <chr>                             <dbl>     <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl>    <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1 pae00650 Butanoate metabolism    0.0764    -1.48  0.0764 0.680       13 0.0764 #> 2 pae01230 Biosynthesis of ami…    0.0773    -1.44  0.0773 0.680       45 0.0773 #> 3 pae00260 Glycine, serine and…    0.0877    -1.39  0.0877 0.680       16 0.0877 #> 4 pae01100 Metabolic pathways      0.0973    -1.30  0.0973 0.680      269 0.0973 #> 5 pae00630 Glyoxylate and dica…    0.118     -1.23  0.118  0.680       11 0.118  #> 6 pae01120 Microbial metabolis…    0.160     -0.999 0.160  0.680       77 0.160  #>  #> $stats #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>   rownames                                 stat.mean  exp1 #>   <chr>                                        <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 pae00470 D-Amino acid metabolism             1.61  1.61  #> 2 pae01232 Nucleotide metabolism               1.24  1.24  #> 3 pae00640 Propanoate metabolism               0.994 0.994 #> 4 pae00330 Arginine and proline metabolism     0.937 0.937 #> 5 pae03010 Ribosome                            0.862 0.862 #> 6 pae01210 2-Oxocarboxylic acid metabolism     0.684 0.684 tr_tidy_gage(gage_untidy, qval = 1) #> # A tibble: 70 × 7 #>    pathway                      p_geomean stat_mean  p_val q_val set_size   exp1 #>    <chr>                            <dbl>     <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl>    <dbl>  <dbl> #>  1 pae00470 D-Amino acid metab…    0.0630     1.61  0.0630 0.924       10 0.0630 #>  2 pae01232 Nucleotide metabol…    0.111      1.24  0.111  0.924       16 0.111  #>  3 pae00640 Propanoate metabol…    0.167      0.994 0.167  0.924       11 0.167  #>  4 pae00330 Arginine and proli…    0.179      0.937 0.179  0.924       14 0.179  #>  5 pae03010 Ribosome               0.197      0.862 0.197  0.924       19 0.197  #>  6 pae01210 2-Oxocarboxylic ac…    0.250      0.684 0.250  0.924       12 0.250  #>  7 pae02040 Flagellar assembly     0.267      0.635 0.267  0.924       11 0.267  #>  8 pae00620 Pyruvate metabolism    0.302      0.526 0.302  0.924       13 0.302  #>  9 pae02024 Quorum sensing         0.327      0.452 0.327  0.924       29 0.327  #> 10 pae00405 Phenazine biosynth…    0.367      0.345 0.367  0.924       10 0.367  #> # title: An overview of tRavis
text: Simple function truncate long strings without breaking middle word. Useful trimming long axis labels plot. ’s can also used inside mutate call:
code: tr_trunc_neatly(   x = "This is a long string that we want to break neatly",   l = 40 ) #> [1] "This is a long string that we want to..." ex_df <- data.frame(   col1 = c(1, 2, 3),   col2 = c(     "This is a pretty long string",     "This string is actually a bit longer",     "Here is the longest string of them all, just!"   ) ) dplyr::mutate(   ex_df,   col3 = purrr::map_chr(col2, ~tr_trunc_neatly(.x, l = 20)) ) #>   col1                                          col2                   col3 #> 1    1                  This is a pretty long string    This is a pretty... #> 2    2          This string is actually a bit longer      This string is... #> 3    3 Here is the longest string of them all, just! Here is the longest...

what: tRavis: an R package by Travis Blimkie
title: tRavis: an R package by Travis Blimkie
text: tRavis small R package contains functions data used regularly day--day workflows. also provides opportunity practice creating, documenting, maintaining code, within framework R package recommended guidelines.

title: tRavis: an R package by Travis Blimkie
text: can install tRavis GitHub :
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("travis-m-blimkie/tRavis")

title: tRavis: an R package by Travis Blimkie
code: library(tRavis) #> Thanks for using tRavis v1.3.25! If you encounter any bugs #> or problems, please submit an issue at the Github page: #> https://github.com/travis-m-blimkie/tRavis/issues # Quickly compare two lists: tr_compare_lists(c(1, 2, 3, 4), c(3, 4, 5, 6), names = c("A", "B")) #> $unique_A #> [1] 1 2 #>  #> $common #> [1] 3 4 #>  #> $unique_B #> [1] 5 6 # Create a named list of files: tr_get_files(   directory = system.file("extdata", package = "tRavis"),   pattern = "test",   date = TRUE,   remove_string = "test_" ) #> $file1 #> [1] "/tmp/RtmpLKGpni/temp_libpath530de3264991/tRavis/extdata/test_file1_20191231.csv" #>  #> $file2 #> [1] "/tmp/RtmpLKGpni/temp_libpath530de3264991/tRavis/extdata/test_file2_20200101.csv" # Neatly truncate strings: tr_trunc_neatly(   x = "This is a long string that we want to break neatly",   l = 40 ) #> [1] "This is a long string that we want to..."

what: Find highest number of reads in a long table — get_rounded_max
title: Find highest number of reads in a long table — get_rounded_max
text: Internal helper takes long tidy data frame containing read count numbers derived MultiQC, finds largest read count value, round nearest ten million.

title: Find highest number of reads in a long table — get_rounded_max
code: get_rounded_max(x, buffer = 1.1, nearest = 1e+07)

title: Find highest number of reads in a long table — get_rounded_max
text: x Data frame read information buffer Multiply largest value factor rounding. Defaults 1.1, .e. adds 10% buffer maximum value. nearest Nearest number round . Defaults 10e6.

title: Find highest number of reads in a long table — get_rounded_max
text: Numeric; maximum number total reads counts

title: Find highest number of reads in a long table — get_rounded_max
text: Input data frame must contain columns "sample" "n_reads".

title: Find highest number of reads in a long table — get_rounded_max
text: None.

title: Clean annotations from pseudomonas.com — tr_anno_cleaner
text: Given input CSV TSV annotation file https://pseudomonas.com, separates cleans data, returning tidy tibble following columns: "locus_tag", "gene_name", "product_name". Setting extra_cols argument TRUE add columns "start", "end", "strand". Enabling fill_names populate missing gene names corresponding locus tag.

title: Clean annotations from pseudomonas.com — tr_anno_cleaner
code: tr_anno_cleaner(input_file, extra_cols = FALSE, fill_names = FALSE)

title: Clean annotations from pseudomonas.com — tr_anno_cleaner
text: input_file Path input TSV CSV file. extra_cols Logical determine start, end, strand columns included. Defaults FALSE. fill_names Logical determine blank/NA genes names filled corresponding locus tag. Defaults FALSE.

title: Clean annotations from pseudomonas.com — tr_anno_cleaner
text: data frame (tibble) cleaned input file

title: Clean annotations from pseudomonas.com — tr_anno_cleaner
text: Download annotation files https://pseudomonas.com

title: Clean annotations from pseudomonas.com — tr_anno_cleaner
code: tr_anno_cleaner(   input_file = paste0(     "https://pseudomonas.com/downloads/pseudomonas/pgd_r_22_1/",     "Pseudomonas_aeruginosa_PAO1_107/Pseudomonas_aeruginosa_PAO1_107.csv.gz"   ) ) #> # A tibble: 5,713 × 3 #>    locus_tag gene_name product_name                                   #>    <chr>     <chr>     <chr>                                          #>  1 PA0001    dnaA      chromosomal replication initiator protein DnaA #>  2 PA0002    dnaN      DNA polymerase III, beta chain                 #>  3 PA0003    recF      RecF protein                                   #>  4 PA0004    gyrB      DNA gyrase subunit B                           #>  5 PA0005    lptA      lysophosphatidic acid acyltransferase, LptA    #>  6 PA0006    NA        conserved hypothetical protein                 #>  7 PA0007    NA        hypothetical protein                           #>  8 PA0008    glyS      glycyl-tRNA synthetase beta chain              #>  9 PA0009    glyQ      glycyl-tRNA synthetase alpha chain             #> 10 PA0010    tag       DNA-3-methyladenine glycosidase I              #> # ℹ 5,703 more rows

title: Tidy results from DESeq2 — tr_clean_deseq2_result
text: Helper function filter sort results DESeq2, aid identifying differentially expressed genes.

title: Tidy results from DESeq2 — tr_clean_deseq2_result
code: tr_clean_deseq2_result(   deseq2_result,   p_adjusted = 0.05,   fold_change = 1.5,   inform = TRUE )

title: Tidy results from DESeq2 — tr_clean_deseq2_result
text: deseq2_result Results object DE genes, class DESeqResults p_adjusted Threshold adjusted p-value. Defaults 0.05. fold_change Threshold absolute fold change. Defaults 1.5. inform message printed name DE comparison number DE genes found? Defaults TRUE.

title: Tidy results from DESeq2 — tr_clean_deseq2_result
text: data frame (tibble) filtered DE genes; see ?DESeq2::results details output.

title: Tidy results from DESeq2 — tr_clean_deseq2_result
text: https://bioconductor.org/packages/DESeq2/

title: Easily compare two lists — tr_compare_lists
text: Performs intersect(x, y), setdiff(x, y), setdiff(y, x). Returns elements list names "common", "unique_x", "unique_y".

title: Easily compare two lists — tr_compare_lists
code: tr_compare_lists(x, y, names = NULL)

title: Easily compare two lists — tr_compare_lists
text: x First vector compare. y Second vector compare. names Optional character vector, containing names x y apply output.

title: Easily compare two lists — tr_compare_lists
text: named list common unique elements x y.

title: Easily compare two lists — tr_compare_lists
text: None.

title: Easily compare two lists — tr_compare_lists

what: Create a named list of files — tr_get_files
title: Create a named list of files — tr_get_files
text: Function creates named list files specified directory. list names trimmed versions file names, contents list file names . way, can easily piped purrr::map(~read.csv(.x)) create named list data frames.

title: Create a named list of files — tr_get_files
code: tr_get_files(   directory,   pattern = "",   recur = FALSE,   date = FALSE,   remove_string = NULL )

title: Create a named list of files — tr_get_files
text: directory Directory containing files read pattern Optional, case-sensitive pattern use file searching. pattern supplied, files specified directory returned. recur Whether file searching listing done recursively. Defaults FALSE. date file names contain date removed? Must formatted akin "YYYYMMDD", .e. numeric spaces, dashes, etc. Defaults FALSE. remove_string Optional string can removed file names creating names output list

title: Create a named list of files — tr_get_files
text: Named list files

title: Create a named list of files — tr_get_files
text: None.

title: Create a named list of files — tr_get_files
code: tr_get_files(   directory = system.file("extdata", package = "tRavis"),   pattern = "test",   remove_string = "test_",   date = TRUE ) #> $file1 #> [1] "/home/runner/work/_temp/Library/tRavis/extdata/test_file1_20191231.csv" #>  #> $file2 #> [1] "/home/runner/work/_temp/Library/tRavis/extdata/test_file2_20200101.csv" #>

what: Create ggplot2 figures from MultiQC results — tr_qc_plots
title: Create ggplot2 figures from MultiQC results — tr_qc_plots
text: Creates four ggplot2 figures MultiQC results, returns data along plot objects. plots FastQC (read counts Phred scores), STAR, HTSeq. See Details information.

title: Create ggplot2 figures from MultiQC results — tr_qc_plots
code: tr_qc_plots(   directory,   type = "bar",   add_points = TRUE,   font_size = 18,   threshold_line = 1e+07,   threshold_line_colour = "#EE2C2C",   threshold_line_type = "dashed",   threshold_line_size = 1,   limits = NULL )

title: Create ggplot2 figures from MultiQC results — tr_qc_plots
text: directory Folder containing data files generated MultiQC, e.g. "multiqc_data/" type Type plot produce, either "bar" (default) "box" add_points Logical: making box plot, individual samples plotted points? Defaults TRUE. font_size Base font size (defaults 18) threshold_line Provide number draw line indicated number reads FastQC read, STAR, HTSeq plots. Defaults 10e6; set NULL disable. threshold_line_colour Colour threshold line ("#EE2C2C") threshold_line_type Type threshold line draw ("dashed"). See ?aes_linetype_size_shape available options. threshold_line_size Size threshold line (1) limits Override upper limit FastQC read, STAR, HTSeq bar plots. Supply single number give three plots limit, vector three values modify individually. Defaults NULL, sets automatic limits.

title: Create ggplot2 figures from MultiQC results — tr_qc_plots
text: list elements "plot" containing ggplot objects, "data" containing underlying data

title: Create ggplot2 figures from MultiQC results — tr_qc_plots
text: Phred scores, one must open MultiQC HTML report, export data "fastqc_per_base_sequence_quality_plot" tab- delimited file (TSV), placing inside directory rest. many samples, data gets saved "mqc_fastqc_per_base_sequence_quality_plot_1.txt"; file also checked automatically. Note "limits" argument applies bar plots - effect box plots. data paired end (.e. R1 R2 sample), read plotted separately FastQC Phred score read number plots. samples named "R1" "R2" found, "R1" removed sample names.

title: Create ggplot2 figures from MultiQC results — tr_qc_plots
text: https://multiqc.info/

title: Create ggplot2 figures from MultiQC results — tr_qc_plots
code: if (FALSE) tr_qc_plots("multiqc_data")

title: Properly sort alphanumeric strings — tr_sort_alphanum
text: Function sort column alphanumeric strings (e.g. c("a1", "a11", "a2")) numeric order (e.g. c("a1", "a2", "a11")). works pipes, can provide column name index argument sort_col.

title: Properly sort alphanumeric strings — tr_sort_alphanum
code: tr_sort_alphanum(input_df, sort_col)

title: Properly sort alphanumeric strings — tr_sort_alphanum
text: input_df Input data frame tibble sorted sort_col Column used sorting index quoted name

title: Properly sort alphanumeric strings — tr_sort_alphanum
text: Sorted data frame

title: Properly sort alphanumeric strings — tr_sort_alphanum
text: None.

title: Properly sort alphanumeric strings — tr_sort_alphanum
code: tr_sort_alphanum(   input_df = data.frame(     colA = c("a11", "a1", "b1", "a2"),     colB = c(3, 1, 4, 2)   ),   sort_col = "colA" ) #>   colA colB #> 2   a1    1 #> 4   a2    2 #> 1  a11    3 #> 3   b1    4

what: Perform a basic enrichment test — tr_test_enrichment
title: Perform a basic enrichment test — tr_test_enrichment
text: Performs Fisher's Exact test determine enrichment set genes interest compared list experimentally derived genes. Uses alternative = "greater" call fisher.test().

title: Perform a basic enrichment test — tr_test_enrichment
code: tr_test_enrichment(query_set, enrichment_set, total_genes)

title: Perform a basic enrichment test — tr_test_enrichment
text: query_set List experimentally otherwise derived genes, one wishes test enrichment enrichment_set Set genes interest, virulence genes total_genes Total number genes organism/species

title: Perform a basic enrichment test — tr_test_enrichment
text: Numeric: raw p-value fisher.test()

title: Perform a basic enrichment test — tr_test_enrichment
text: ?stats::fisher.test

title: Perform a basic enrichment test — tr_test_enrichment
code: all_genes <- paste0("gene", sample(1:10000, 5000)) de_genes <- sample(all_genes, 1500) ex_set <- sample(all_genes, 100)  tr_test_enrichment(   query_set = de_genes,   enrichment_set = ex_set,   total_genes = 5000 ) #> [1] 0.05127792

title: Customized ggplot2 theme — tr_theme
text: Custom theme can applied ggplot2 plots. Increases base font size, sets white background, grey grid, black border.

title: Customized ggplot2 theme — tr_theme
code: tr_theme(base_size = 18, base_family = "", grid = TRUE)

title: Customized ggplot2 theme — tr_theme
text: base_size Base font size applied text plot base_family Base font type applies text plot grid Determines grid lines drawn. Defaults TRUEfor "major" grid lines drawn.

title: Customized ggplot2 theme — tr_theme
text: ggplot2 theme

title: Customized ggplot2 theme — tr_theme
text: None.

title: Customized ggplot2 theme — tr_theme
code: if (FALSE)   ggplot(mtcars, aes(cyl, mpg)) + geom_point() + tr_theme()

what: Coerce Gage output to a tidy data frame — tr_tidy_gage
title: Coerce Gage output to a tidy data frame — tr_tidy_gage
text: function simply convert output Gage enrichment easier--use tibble format. time can also filter result based q value, default 0.1.

title: Coerce Gage output to a tidy data frame — tr_tidy_gage
code: tr_tidy_gage(gage_result, qval = 0.1)

title: Coerce Gage output to a tidy data frame — tr_tidy_gage
text: gage_result list output call gage::gage qval Cutoff q value, defaults 0.1

title: Coerce Gage output to a tidy data frame — tr_tidy_gage
text: data frame (tibble)

title: Coerce Gage output to a tidy data frame — tr_tidy_gage
text: None.

title: Cleanly trim long strings — tr_trunc_neatly
text: Trims input string desired length, appending ellipsis end, without splitting middle word.

title: Cleanly trim long strings — tr_trunc_neatly
code: tr_trunc_neatly(x, l = 60)

title: Cleanly trim long strings — tr_trunc_neatly
text: x Input string trim desired length, appending ellipsis end, without splitting words l Desired length trim strings

title: Cleanly trim long strings — tr_trunc_neatly
text: Character string

title: Cleanly trim long strings — tr_trunc_neatly
text: None.

title: Cleanly trim long strings — tr_trunc_neatly
code: tr_trunc_neatly("This is a test string", l = 17) #> [1] "This is a test..."
